description: Maintained by the Consul team at HashiCorp. Displays critical health metrics about Consul servers, which are key to understanding Consul servers' behavior and stability in production. Also offers pre-built sections and panels for understanding usage of Consul by feature such as: KVs, DNS, the Catalog, and ACLs.

panels.description: avg(consul_raft_commitTime_95_percentile)
panels.title: Raft Commit Time (p95)

panels.description: avg(max(consul_raft_leader_lastContact{quantile="0.9"}))
panels.title: Raft Leader Last Contact

panels.description: sum(avg_over_time(consul_kvs_apply[1m])) by (instance)
panels.title: KV Apply Time (mean)

panels.description: This will show 1 in the case of 0, that is because of Grafana saying "UNHEALTHY" which is untrue.
panels.title: Raft Index Difference

options.content:
# Overview

The key metric for Consul health is KV Apply Time, which represents the write latency and throughput of the entire cluster.

Mean KV Apply Time < 3,000ms is considered Healthy. < 1,000ms is ideal.

See graph at right for current status.

panels.title: Transaction Timing - should be consistent; a few ms

panels.description: A boolean value that will show 1 if there are no issues, and 0 if autopilot has detected an issue. First, ensure that the cluster has an operational leader. If so, ensure that all nodes have sufficient IO throughput and memory.
panels.title: Autopilot Health

panels.description:
Measures the time spent applying a transaction operation.

NOTE: If there are too many timeseries here from clients, consider filtering down to server hosts. You can set this with a prometheus scrape target based on the node's role.
panels.title: Transaction Apply Time

panels.description:
TODO Interrogate the rate interval more
Rate of raft commits per server cluster. The commit count is emitted by the leader and can be considered authoritative across a datacenter.
panels.title: Raft Transaction Apply Time

panels.description:
Measures the time it takes to commit a new entry to the Raft log on the leader.

NOTE: If there are too many timeseries here from clients, consider filtering down to server hosts. You can set this with a prometheus scrape target based on the node's role.
panels.title: Raft Commit Time

panels.description:
This measures the time it takes to complete an update to the KV store.

NOTE: If there are too many timeseries here from clients, consider filtering down to server hosts. You can set this with a prometheus scrape target based on the node's role.
panels.title: KV Apply Time
Consul Server Cluster Health - Leadership and Autopilot

panels.description:
0 is bad, 1 is ok, >1 is good
Number of voting servers that the local server cluster can lose while continuing to function.
panels.title: Autopilot Fault Tolerance w/o RZ

panels.description: Shows the duration since an agent had last seen the leader. Spikes here may indicate network issues or a leader slowing or becoming unavailable.
panels.title: Raft Leader Last Contacted

panels.description: This panel should show "`No data`" in a stable cluster. Some leadership transition events are expected, such as during cluster upgrades. Unexpected events may indicate an issue with cluster stability.
panels.title: Raft Election Events - stack

panels.description:
~ ns is normal
> 2s/minute is not good
> 5s/min is bad
Number of nanoseconds consumed by stop-the-world garbage collection (GC) pauses since Consul started.
panels.title: Runtime Total GC Pause per 1m
Network Activity - RPC Count - current load created from Agents

panels.description:
Increments whenever a Consul agent in client mode makes an RPC request to a Consul server
* gets rate limited by that agent's limits configuration
* or fails.
panels.title: Consul Client RPC Query Exceeded/Failed
[TODO] Please ensure Consul has CPU, Disk, Memory, and Network bandwidth headroom available! We recommend creating panels here, querying your host stats for each.

panels.description: sum(rate(container_network_receive_bytes_total{image!="",name=~"consul-.*"}[5m])) by (name)
panels.title: Network Bytes Send and Received

panels.description: sum(rate(container_network_receive_bytes_total{image!="",name=~"consul-.*"}[5m])) by (name)
panels.title: Network Packets Send and Received

panels.description: Shows the rate of domain queries per node, bucketed into 5 minute intervals.
panels.title: DNS Queries per interval

panels.description: Shows the time spent handling a domain queries for each node. A spike here may indicate that there are too many concurrent domain queries, or the catalog is under high contention.
panels.title: DNS Domain Query Time

panels.description: Show the time spent handling a reverse DNS query for the given node.
panels.title: DNS Reverse Query Time

panels.description: Shows the rate of KV operations in 5 minute buckets.
panels.title: KV Applies per 5m

panels.description:
This measures the time it takes to complete an update to the KV store.

NOTE: If there are too many timeseries here from clients, consider filtering down to server hosts. You can set this with a prometheus scrape target based on the node's role.
panels.title: KV Apply Time

panels.description: Measures the time spent applying transaction operations.
panels.title: Transaction Apply Time

panels.description: Counts how many ACL tokens are resolved and buckets them by 5 minute intervals.
panels.title: ACL Resolves per 5min

panels.description: Times how long it takes to resolve an ACL Token into its policies.
panels.title: ACL ResolveToken Time

panels.description: This counts the number of times we've updated an ACL, bucketed into 5 minute intervals.
panels.title: ACL Updates per 5m

panels.description: This measures the time it takes to complete an update to the ACL store.
panels.title: ACL Apply Time

panels.description: This shows the rate of increase for catalog register and deregister operations.
panels.title: Catalog Operations per 5m

panels.description: Measures the time it takes to complete catalog register or deregister operations.
panels.title: Catalog Operation Time

panels.description: Tracks the number of running goroutines and is a general load pressure indicator. This may burst from time to time but should return to a steady state value.
panels.title: Go Routines by Server

panels.description: Increments when a server receives a read RPC request, indicating the rate of new read queries.
panels.title: Consul RPC Health

panels.description:
fsm.apply The number of logs committed since the last interval.
fsm.register - Measures the time it takes to apply a catalog register operation to the FSM.
panels.title: Consul Finite State Machine (p99)

panels.description: This increments for each health query for the given service.
panels.title: Top 5 Queried Services by Health

title: Consul Server Monitoring from grafana Peter
